reviewText:
A Stendhal Syndrome inducing piece of art, that becomes David Kanaga’s most ambitious work to date
I should start this review by saying that after the first 20 minutes I spent with Fernando Ramallo and David Kanaga’s new creation, I feel forced to stop in a state of anxiety while tears of emotion blurred my eyes.

Panoramical puts me in the same state of euphoria that Stendhal felt visiting the Basilica of Santa Croce in Florence for the first time, as he became overwhelmed by the dazzling beauty found in Giotto’s frescoes.

And you should take into account that I was skeptical about Panoramical, based on my prior experience with David Kanaga’s first work, Proteus. Because, well, Proteus is one of my all-time favourite art pieces. A giant leap in the of use of the videogame medium to express mature and philosophical subjects, taking advantage of its interactive elements to maximize the spectator involvement with a natural and surreal environment. A contemplative but also narrative masterwork, that evokes Andrei Tarkovsky’s existentialist films. And all of these elements were emphasized by the experimental approach of David Kanaga regarding musical composition. Using layers of sounds, like a painter that selects from a range of colors to fill a blank canvas with joyful and hedonistic emotions.

So, I was skeptical about Panoramical because contrary to Proteus and its narrative approach, now we’re talking of a fully abstract creation, that also implies taking a lot of new risks in its conception. Proteus was a pleasant and absorbing experience thanks to its magnificent artistic and musical design. But it also succeeded in touching the player’s heart with its psychological and complex structure, based in the recurrent art theme of using a seasons cycle as a metaphor to express an entire human life. The childhood innocence and sense of magical discovery of a new world full of stimulations in the spring. The fauna at its plethora in the summer, like a metaphor of the puberty. The quietness realization of maturity in an autumn envolved by sad and dissonant musical notes. The terrifying and ominous proximity of death in the winter, where the life forms are replaced with sinister tombs. And a final cycle of ascension to an elevated and deeper plane of reality, full of hope, where you finally close your eyes, with an emotional fade to black conclusion.

But after I can finally experiment Panoramical, and while I still remain exhilarated with its sheer beauty, I can say that is the most ambitious work created by David Kanaga to date. And that his ability to create pure and intense emotions in the spectator still remains intact. If Proteus was an impressionist painting based on the theme of nature, Panoramical is more close to Kandinsky abstract creations, affecting the player’s perception in subtle and unconscious ways. And it has one of the most impressive virtual environments conceived in the interactive art medium since Tetsuya Mizoguchi’s Rez.

Fernando Ramallo and David Kanaga’s new creation will appeal not only to Proteus fans, but also to all the admirers of Toshio Iwai’s underground cult classic Electroplankton. Like Electroplankton, Panoramical is a fascinating toy for musical creation, with an extremely original control scheme based in the use of a MIDI controller, that also fits perfectly a gamepad button layout. But unlike Electroplankton or the also similar Cosmic DJ, Panoramical has the ambition of being much more that a simple musical toy. Becoming a complex rehearse about the use of geometry forms and musical patterns to create intense and vivid emotions in the player, but also serving as a tool for intimate artistic expression.

( The writer of this review is not an English native. So you should expect occasional grammar errors. I apologize in advance. )

reviewText:
SUMMARY: A musical/visual game where you manipulate various settings to create your own visual/musical combinations.  Worth purchasing if you enjoy experiential games, and like unusual musical and video experiences.

Panoramical is best summed up as an audio/visual toy.  It's a kind of spiritual lovechild of screensavers, Proteus, and  the Atari C-240.

As you play (with minimal instruction) you enter various settings.  In those you have nine factors you can maniuplate - there's no directions, you have to find what they do.  Each factor alters both the musical and the visual landscape - what could be a mysterious black and white swamp, with a few tweaks, becomes a strange mirrored plain with shooting stars flying about.  Music could be dissonant, orchestral, whimsical, or something else.

Each world presents different factors, effects, and sounds - and it's up to you to figure them out.  You can make amazing things with this game if you take the time.

One thing I came up with early on when playing was to simply mix a world then leave it on in the background.  Just let the music and world I made fill the room while I worked.

Pretty much you can tell right now if you'd like this game.  If you like things that are unusual and experimental, especially in the audio/visual vein, then you're probably already buying it.  If you're looking for something strange and fun to play with, you may consider it.  If you're looking for a traditional game with some funky graphics and music, it's probably not your bag.

I will note that the same above applies for gifts.  If it's not for you but you've got that friend who loves her weird electronica or he loves playing with graphics, you just found a great present.

Pass on it or spend hours jamming out to imaginary music worlds, your choice.  But it is a nice job of programming and obviously made with a love of music.

reviewText:
Panoramical can be seen as both game and software, and it's unlike anything on Steam, that's for sure. It practically allows you to generate your own abstract scenes within the game limits.

There are 15 scenes and you have 9 switches to manipulate them: change environments, add effects, make that percussion sound to be faster, etc. It sounds pretty basic and boring when you read it, but in the game it feels like pure magic and you can't say for sure what do you change exactly, how it affects the scene and what is going on.
The music (entirely electronic, of course) fits very well and adds to the atmosphere, although some of the tracks are pretty chaotic and feel entirely randomly generated (I believe to some extent they are).

The process is fairly simple – you hold a button and move a stick, either right or left one, depends on which button you hold. You hold the left stick once you're finished and move on to the next scene.

The game feels well polished and I didn't find any technical problems with it. The interface is excellent, very stylish.

It's an essential buy for people who like watching abstract/trippy art / scenes / video / you get it. It can be useful for meditations, trips or just watching it for the sake of its mesmerizing beauty.

Review key provided by the developer
Sasha Darko for Game Obscura

reviewText:
You find yourself in this ever moving forest of black little hills, shooting purple stars, yellow bubbles and ethereal looking sheets of white. You can manipulate them and change them into something else. The sounds seem to move along with the changes or is it the visuals that move along with the sounds? It doesn't matter. Behind me, my boyfriend tells me later, the cats were breaking down the house, but I was completely oblivious and sucked into my screen. Yes I was on a trip. A journey.

allthought I write a lot of reviews for websites and newspapers, this is actually the first time I decided to write something on Steam. I feel like I have to, there are people who don't get this game and I'm not saying that my vision is THE way to interpret it. But it got to me in a way where I just have to share my experience of this game.  Or is it even a game? It acts as a crossover between a game and sound-editing program with trippy visuals. But really I see it as participatory art.

It completely rips up the whole concept of 'game' and what we expect of it, and that to me is what makes it even more fascinating. It starts right out with the intro and menu being so incredibly organic, instead of the typical list of buttons you can click, it's a dial that looks almost like a living organism. It's incredibly easy to start 'playing', the controls are very intuitive. I think a game like this encourages natural play a lot more than some other bigger games out there, where you have to follow certain paths in very constrictive ways.

The music goes from angelic to stomping to racing and back again, it's mellow and then it's intense. You can adapt it like you are the creator of this little musical universe that keeps on moving and hypnotizing you. It is like you can SEE the music, a concept called synthesia, where the different areas of the brain that control our senses get connected or mixed up. Normally only people with a rare condition, or people on psychedelics get to experience this. And now we can sit behind our screens, completely sober and touch on that magical experience. Allthough I must admit being high makes it even more immersive - if you can handle, try it! Pretty sure that makers had a few trips that inspired them to make this.

I must admit thought, if you're sensitive to bright lights and flashy visuals, be careful cause it's VERY intense. I'm glad I'm on preventative medication for migraines, else I would probably, or rather definitely have had an attack from this game. Having said that, I can't really discover anything else that I didn't like about this game.

Of course it's a matter of taste if you like it and since it's so different, I'm pretty sure it will be a niche group that will be drawn to this game. But I guess it's the same with art, not everyone likes it in the first place and then there's all the different types of art. If you go to a museum you might pay ten euros for the entrance and look at still lives of similar visuals. Now you get to participate, make music, manipulate visuals and even make sceenshots of your trip. I think it's well worth the money and I would love to see more of the makers.

Also I think that it works different than a regular game where you level up and go through the story and then you finish after 50 hours. This is an experience, and I feel I would like to go back to that experience every once in a while, but not hours at a time.

After playing this I feel stimulated, refreshed and inspired. Something like a meditation.

reviewText: Maybe this just isn't for me, but I feel disappointed. I'd been interested because of David Kanaga's earlier “Proteus”, which I'd returned to many times to wander around in and relax. I'd been looking for the same but more, and I didn't find it here. After a bit under an hour, I've whizzed through all of the scenes here, at least up to unlocking inverted mode, and I can't see myself coming back. There's a bit of beauty here, but also a bit of chaos and ugliness. All the same, I feel bad for not liking Panoramical. Others might find more in it.

reviewText:
This game is really novel, but one thing all of the glowing reviews on every single tech website didn't tell me was this: it's a LOT easier to make noise than it is to make anything remotely resembling music. After an hour of playing, I'm still not even really sure if this is by design or not.

Don't expect to jam, don't expect a melody - expect it to sound more like several people plunking random notes on several keyboards at once while someone else provides the rhythm" by plunking more random notes.

If you can figure out which control makes an atmospheric choir sound and turn it up

reviewText: On the one hand, I can see this game as a glorified screensaver, albeit one with pretty colors and sounds.  If you approach this game passively, just turning the knobs here and there and hoping that something will be revealed to you, then a  screensaver  pretty much sums it up.\n\nHowever, if you approach it more actively and imaginatively, then it can be much more.  I think of those Japanese sand gardens.  You know, rake the sand and make ripples" and now the rocks and pebbles are mountains and islands
date: and you see a whole world being created – a reflection of how you see the world.  The game in this way is intensely personal and meditative.\n\nThere are similarities with Proteus - colors and abstracted shapes and sounds.  But Proteus spells out the world pretty clearly for us to explore - paths
voteText: day and night;  here
helpfulPercent: what you see is mostly a reflection of what you imagine; what you imagine is then reinforced by what you see."

reviewText:
Ok, so basically, I rarely pay 10 euros for a game on Steam but this seemed like a worthy project to contribute to.
Initially i found the game really well executed for the target audience it would have.
This is actually not so much of a game as it is a series of prerendered interactive visualisations and music, this should be clear to anyone who doubts this.
Anyhow, the music and sound selections are mostly really well picked and the visual effects are rendered in a very pleasant way, offering a ton of variation when you have control over what happens.

I do find the selection of songs/stages still rather limited at the moment and not showing the maximal strenghts of the games appeal. Overall, the music hangs in a kind of adjustable steady flow which creates a calm, meditating sense of play but it can get a bit repetitive and too much in the ambient genre. Personally, I prefer the  stages that include a certain sense of advancement in them. the first and last stages portray this nicely and especially the selection of guest stages fare best in this matter.

I hope the developers will find a way to bring some more content to the game or ideally create an editor for users to create more stages themselves. That would make the possibilities endless.

Still it's a worthy and refreshing experience hard to be disliked!
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
PANORAMICAL delivered exactly what i wanted.
It brings a unique gaming experience in which the visual content directly influences the audio.
There is no Goal, it is only you creating what you want to create.

At first i was astonished, in the first few minutes i already had a kind of tunnel vision and didnt really notice things happening around me.

The great thing about the game is, that it is what you want it to be.
You can create a calming scene or something fast-paced.
It is up to you to decide.
The best moments in the game are, when you have a vision and, you take your time to fulfill that vision, but you can of course just go wild with it and have your fun.

It was only at some point in which i thought that what i see doesnt quite fit in with what i hear.
I didnt like a few of the settings, but you always could, with enought effort, create a scene worth sitting back and enjoying the music and visuals.

I hope there will be new content, i would even be ok with paid content if its for the right price.

I recommend some good sativa, nice headphones and an open Mind.

All in all i think it is safe to say that this game is the 2. Best game in 2015 close behind Fallout 4

reviewText: I took a trip this evening and never left my chair. Absorbing, hypnotizing, mesmerizing! Awesome chill-out visualizer. As the visuals morph and change, so does the soundtrack. A glorified screensaver it is NOT!  Jeff Minter's 'Psychodelia' on the C64 (1984) was for me the grandpa of light synths. Panoramical takes things to a whole new incredible level. A thing of beauty. A digital 'van gogh'. Highly recommended!

reviewText:
This is absolutely the kind of thing to play when you want to just let the experience wash over you.

On my first pass through, I had some real favorite soundscapes and some not-so-favorites. However, sitting down one evening using my headphones and much-larger-than-my-monitor television I found myself really enjoying every scene. I do sort of wish that the music/sound could be decoupled from the visuals in a few cases where I really liked the audio, but tweaking it to that state resulted in things like color schemes I didn't love. But! It's still lovely, even when the designers made choices I don't entirely agree with.

And, let's be honest, this is exactly the sort of experience that most people will find pairs very well with recreational brain chemistry modification.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Who came up with the idea of an interactive abstract art piece to modify to your heart's content, changing the sky and the water and the ground...if they exist? I mean, it IS abstract. Who knows what all that stuff is.
The guests were great too. The disco-like triangle place with a strange pulsating red thing and a upbeat soundtrack, the floating city on the water with purple rings to dive through, the realistic-looking scrolling city...so beautiful.
I'm yet to play inverted mode, and I've only played each scene once, but the time I've spent on this game so far were worth it.
If you think a game needs a way to win, a way to die, and a way to score points, then don't get PANORAMICAL. But, like me, if you don't think a game needs that stuff, then get this game. Or is it a game? I'm not sure...
But whatever. If your definition of a game is a picture you control, preferably a pretty one, then you'll love PANORAMICAL.
It's perfect.

To Fernando Ramallo ,	David Kanaga, and all others involved... thank you so very much.

reviewText: Ten bucks for an experimental soundtrack that lets you control the ebb and flow of the music, 100% worth every penny.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
I wouldn't consider this a game, but more of an audio visual experience. The experience is comprised of around 12 different stages, each of which have their own visual theme and music track. The way you play the game is by triggering disparate parts of the visual scene and audio track, melding them into a unique combination of all the elements. In writing it is slightly difficult to convey how the game works, but it is easy to grasp in practice and the effect is enchanting.

This is not really a game that anyone needs, but it is a wonderful experience to have, especially if you have a good audio/visual setup in your gaming environment. I played this on a 120 projected display with DTS sound and it blew my mind.

Interestingly
date: Panoramical can be played with a MIDI controller (used for music production) as well as a gamepad or keyboard and mouse."
